topic.name: A Theology of Place
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for A Theology of Place in Geography

objectives.objective_text: Identify that God owns the world, we just live here.
Name kindness to animals as a good thing.
Identify a neighbor as anyone we meet.
Name being kind to strangers as good.
Identify people as gardeners of the world.
Name taking care of pets and plants as our job.
Identify 'Home' as a special place.
Name where I come from.
Identify the world as something God made good.
Name rocks, trees, and water as God's gifts.
Recall that God feeds the birds.
Observe that we should not waste water or food.
Recall the Good Samaritan.
Observe that people from other countries are God's children too.
Recall that we shouldn't ruin God's world.
Observe that littering is bad stewardship.
Recall that Jesus had a hometown (Nazareth).
Observe that where we live shapes what we do.
Recall that God likes what He made.
Observe beauty in nature.
Summarize why we protect nature (because God made it).
Explain that humans are more important than animals (Image of God).
Explain the 'Tragedy of the Commons'.
Defend the priority of human flourishing alongside creation care.
Summarize the command to love the stranger.
Explain what hospitality means (making room for others).
Explain the biblical origin of nations (Babel and Pentecost).
Defend the dignity of every ethnicity and culture.
Summarize the Dominion Mandate (Genesis 1:28).
Explain the difference between 'using' and 'using up'.
Explain the Christian duty to manage resources wisely.
Defend a balanced view of dominion that rejects abuse.
Summarize how geography changes how people live (food, clothes).
Explain that God placed us where we are for a reason.
Explain the concept of 'inculturation' of the Gospel.
Defend the value of local community commitments.
Summarize 'God saw that it was good' (Genesis 1).
Explain that matter (stuff) is not evil.
Explain why we care for the earth.
Defend the goodness of the material world against asceticism.
Compare Christian care for nature with worshipping nature.
Apply conservation to daily habits.
Analyze the difference between 'Conservation' and 'Preservation'.
Interpret biblical laws regarding land rest and animal care.
Connect environmental degradation to sin and greed.
Compare fear of strangers (Xenophobia) with love of strangers.
Apply global awareness to prayer for the nations.
Analyze the Old Testament laws regarding the 'Sojourner'.
Interpret the Great Commission (make disciples of all nations).
Connect geography to the distribution of unreached people groups.
Compare a good ruler (steward) with a bad ruler (tyrant).
Apply the idea of tending and keeping the earth.
Analyze the concept of Stewardship vs. Exploitation.
Interpret the Fall's impact on the ground (thorns and thistles).
Connect human flourishing to environmental health.
Compare city life with country life in the Bible.
Apply gratitude for our own community.
Analyze how physical environment shapes culture (Environmental Determinism vs Possibilism).
Interpret the connection between land and identity in the OT.
Connect the loss of place (Exile) to spiritual crisis.
Compare a biblical view of nature with a Gnostic view (body is bad).
Apply thankfulness for the physical world.
Analyze the dualism of Gnosticism vs. Biblical Realism.
Interpret Psalm 19 and Psalm 104 (God's glory in nature).
Connect the Incarnation (Jesus becoming flesh) to the value of matter.
Evaluate the secular environmental movement (strengths/weaknesses).
Evaluate current immigration issues through a biblical lens.
Evaluate the Industrial Revolution's impact on the theology of work.
Evaluate the modern feeling of 'placelessness'.
Evaluate the New Age worship of nature vs. Christian stewardship.
Construct a Christian environmental ethic.
Synthesize Romans 8 (creation groaning) with Christian hope.
Construct a theology of nations and borders (Acts 17:26).
Synthesize global missiology with cultural geography.
Construct an ethic of creation care based on Imago Dei.
Synthesize economic development with environmental responsibility.
Construct an analysis of how geography influences worldview.
Synthesize the Christian identity as 'elect exiles' (1 Peter).
Construct a theological defense of the physical resurrection.
Synthesize the 'New Heavens and New Earth' as a restored physical place.
